sta 1. A delict is usually defined as a violation of a ius in rem which ge· nerates an obligation remissible by the private individual who is wronged. This, though it serves to distinguish delict, as a source of obligations, from contract, and as a private wrong from a crime, is insufficient when applied to Roman law. Such wrongs as the withholding os possession by 3 defendant who bona ride believes in his own title are not delicts, at any rate in the specific sense in which the term is used in the 13- stitutes; they give rise, it is true, to a right of action, but a right ol action is a different thing srom an obligatio ex delicto: they are redressed by mere reparation, by the wrong-doer being compelled to put the other in the position in which he would have been had the wrong never been committed. But delicts, as contrasted with them and with contracts‚ possess three peculiarities. The obligations which arise from them are independent, and do not merely modiiy obligations already subsisting: they always involve dolus or culpa; and the remedies by which they are redressed are penal. From every true delict arises an obligation to pay a penalty to the person who pursues it; and irom every delict which causes damnum or proprietary loss arises also an obligatior to com- pensate the injured person sor that loss.
